It appears there is a new call to version.getFullPath(), where version implements IStorage, which fails for the following remote CM path:
\Rep1\jbtest1\com\ca\Class1.java

The file can be found locally at:
C:\dev\eclipse-3.2\eclipse\runtime-workspace\.metadata\.plugins\com.myplugin.ui\~Temp-49-191-129\Class1.java
We call EFS.getLocalFileSystem().getStore(location); with a non-null location.

(In reply to comment #3)
> We call EFS.getLocalFileSystem().getStore(location); with a non-null location.
> 

Is this a new call for 3.2?  My file is located at the file location mentioned above, and I can open it in an editor launched with that location.  Is there a problem with the path?

(In reply to comment #5)

I am not implementing IPath myself.

version is a class that implements IStorageEditorInput, IStorage, IStructureComparator, ITypedElement, IStreamContentAccessor

Though not practical, if I return null from version.getFullPath(), then it works.
Can you see in the debugger how it is ending up with a null value?

(In reply to comment #7)
> Can you see in the debugger how it is ending up with a null value?
> 

I haven't been able to trace the instantiation of LocalFile with null.

What does your editor input return currently for IStorage.getFullPath()?  I.e., what is the output of IStorage.getFullPath().toString() in this case?  The editor framework is incorrectly assuming that IStorage.getFullPath() is returning a local file system path or a workspace path.  This shouldn't cause an NPE, but knowing the exact path that you are returning in this case would help diagnose further.

(In reply to comment #9)

I have already given this information.  Here it is once again.  getFullPath() returns the following on my Windows XP system:
C:\dev\eclipse-3.2\eclipse\runtime-workspace\.metadata\.plugins\com.myplugin.ui\~Temp-49-191-129\Class1.java

(In reply to comment #9)

Sorry - misunderstood your question, the file is located at the location specified.

getFullPath() = \Rep1\jbtest1\com\Class1.java

Local location = C:\dev\eclipse-3.2\eclipse\runtime-workspace\.metadata\.plugins\com.myplugin.ui\~Temp-49-191-129\Class1.java

(In reply to comment #12)

Well, if I return null from getFullPath() it works.  If I return my CM repository location, \Rep1\jbtest1\com\Class1.java, it throws the NullPointerException.
This happens for a Java file in the 3.2 GA release.
I have not been able to reproduce this and still don't see how the NPE can happen. I think your editor input must be doing something strange.

(In reply to comment #15)
> I have not been able to reproduce this and still don't see how the NPE can
> happen. I think your editor input must be doing something strange.
> 

As I have mentioned before, if I return 'null' from getFullPath() it works fine.  Otherwise, I return a database repository location (e.g. \rep\test\file.java).  This location is not a reachable location, which must be related to the problem.

Also, won't you concede that if my editor input was "strange" that the NPE would result from all types of editors, not just the Java editor as is the case?  Text files (e.g. \rep\test\file.txt) work fine with the default editor.

> Also, won't you concede that if my editor input was "strange" that the NPE
> would result from all types of editors, not just the Java editor as is the
> case? 

I could equally argue that if the editors were at fault, the NPE would occur using all editor inputs, but it only occurs using *your* editor input. Clearly neither of those arguments are conclusive.

If you could set a breakpoint in the debugger and see how the NPE is occurring, that would be useful.  As it stands, it appears to be impossible for an NPE to occur at that line as I have described in comment #5.

My point is that the Java editor is using getFullPath() differently than other editors.

If you can describe to me the specifics of what breakpoint to set, and where, then I will consider doing it.  I don't have a lot of time to devote to debugging into Eclipse at this time.

My point is that the Java editor is using getFullPath() differently than other editors.

If you can describe to me the specifics of what breakpoint to set, and where, then I will consider doing it.  I don't have a lot of time to devote to debugging into Eclipse at this time.
I would start with a breakpoint in the second stack frame: LocalFileSystem.getStore(LocalFileSystem.java:118).

Just some other ideas:
1) could it be a VM bug? What VM are you using? Try with disabled JIT
2) attach your (stripped) code that allows us to reproduce the bug

Leopold: are you sure you are seeing the same issue? I don't see the same NullPointerException in the log you attached to bug 149713. No progress is being made on this bug because from analysis of the code the exception is not possible (see comment #5).  I cannot reproduce it, and the originator hasn't provided a reproducible test case. If you can reproduce the same problem and would like to help diagnose this further, see my comment #17 and comment #20.

John, why don't you debug, and change the return from getFullPath() to the string I mentioned (\rep\test\file.txt).  On a Java file, you should see the NullPointerException.  Have you tried this?  What gives you confidence that it can't happen?

John:

The reason why I have attached my scenario is because to point of entry is the same as this Bug:

at org.eclipse.swt.custom.BusyIndicator.showWhile(BusyIndicator.java:67)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchPage.openEditor(WorkbenchPage.java:2493)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchPage.openEditor(WorkbenchPage.java:2478)
	at dbedit.ui.editor.table.OpenEditorAction.openEditor(OpenEditorAction.java:134)

With almost the same line (2478 instead of 2470). So, IFF you think, that is a total other issue, then I shift to another Bug. But when this Bug was opened the  introduction reminded my very well to my current situation: '...get ... in 3.2M6, but not in 3.1.2' 

=> What is next to do?

Leopold, the code which is the same is the generic code to open an editor with an editor input. Almost all code that opens anything in any editor goes through there.

While this bug ends with an NPE when creating a LocalFile your bug fails because of a missing (or wrong) command context. Which of course doesn't tell us for sure that this doesn't originate from the same cause. 

John, just a wild guess: given that the bug didn't happen in 3.2 and appears in 3.2.1, might it be possible that what they see is similar to bug 155996 i.e. two instance of the same plug-in being active and causing strange behavior? Note however that the File Buffer plug-in *is* marked as singleton.
==> can the bug reporters check this: start Eclipse with -clean and check whether the bug goes away.

Another thing to check is the VM: run with disabled JIT and check whether the bug is still present.
The bug did happen in 3.2, but did not happen in 3.1.2.
Comment 30 also applies for that scenario. Did you try -clean?
If you are asking me, I used a clean install with a clean workspace.
OK, then I suggest to attach a test case that demonstrates the bug i.e. either attach your plug-in or strip it down if it contains confidential material.

You, nor John, have answered my question.  Have you debugged with setting the String returned from getFullPath(), on a Java editor opening, to the String I have mentioned several times?  This should be a simple way to test the problem, that supposedly can't happen.  Then, debug with passing 'null' as the return and it will work.
Marking it WORKSFORME
